item.title: Has Pok√©mon Winds And Waves Finally Ended The Series‚Äô Graphics Problem?
item.content:encoded:
Well, folks, it looks like Pok√©mon Winds and Waves may have finally broken the series‚Äô bad graphics curse. At least, that‚Äôs what it looks like based on the first trailer, which appears to be a marked visual improvement over Scarlet and Violet, which have become a poster child for the series‚Äô poor technical performance.

Scarlet and Violet, released in 2022, were the last Switch-exclusive Pok√©mon games, and were heavily derided for not only being a buggy mess, but for looking like a GameCube tech demo. They had a big map that had no real texture or life to it. When they got a Switch 2 update, they ran at a buttery smooth 60 frames-per-second, but they still looked really rough and old. Winds and Waves, meanwhile, have a notable technical and graphical leap, with much more dynamic lighting, shading, and water physics. The Pok√©mon themselves have a bit of texture to them similar to Scarlet and Violet‚Äôs models, but beyond that, any direct comparisons we might make work in Winds and Waves‚Äô favor. I‚Äôd still argue that it doesn‚Äôt look incredible by any stretch, but it definitely is the most dynamic-looking Pok√©mon game we‚Äôve had in a while.

It was WILD comparing the new trailer, to the first real trailer of Scarlet and Violet. I'm flabbergasted! pic.twitter.com/FIKnM4ueq0

‚Äî Ron (@Truegreen7) February 27, 2026

Um comparativo gr√°fico entre a √°gua renderizada na nona e na d√©cima gera√ß√£o de Pok√©mon (em desenvolvimento): pic.twitter.com/1dmMxLvVH6

‚Äî 'Necro' Felipe #UnivNintendo (@necrolipe) February 27, 2026

HOW DID WE GO FROM POKEMON SCARLET/VIOLET TO THIS??? pic.twitter.com/SJBVafeFA6

‚Äî Yisuno ‚öù | GECQUA ENJOYER (@TheYisusOne) February 27, 2026

pokemon pic.twitter.com/HrEmYWb4KU

‚Äî gooompy (@Gooompy) February 27, 2026

water has always been a huge part of Pok√©mon's worlds and it's SUCH a relief to see Winds and Waves fix the gross flat plains that have plagued every 3D release thus far pic.twitter.com/dcirZnFeT9

‚Äî Lewtwo (@Lewchube) February 27, 2026

notice how pokemon started looking good the minute we got out of europe

‚Äî lil (@adifying) February 27, 2026

I‚Äôm ready to move on pic.twitter.com/grP5QlH7m2

‚Äî Ant (@antdude92) February 27, 2026

i love how they showed us various windmills rotating smoothly to demonstrate that they learned how to animate them properly this time pic.twitter.com/3qiByBPNMx

‚Äî jamie ‚ñ¥ (@linkkling) February 27, 2026

Para los que dicen que Winds & Waves se ven iguales que S/V‚Ä¶

¬ø¬ø¬°¬°ACASO EST√ÅN CIEGOS?!??

Escarlata parece un juego de la 64 comparado con la d√©cima generaci√≥n pic.twitter.com/Z5WGVSnP9A

‚Äî JV (@JVindahouse) February 27, 2026

Is it enough to wash off the stink of older, uglier games? We‚Äôll have to see how the game holds up when it eventually launches, but critics of the series‚Äô past technical performance aren‚Äôt about to back down just because Game Freak is taking the time to polish its games after years of poor performance and visuals.

"All the haters need to apologize now for-" No. The 'hate' was totally earned and valid. People are happy they're finally making the effort and hopefully will keep holding them to this higher standard.

I just hope they remember to put in an interesting story this time. Voiced‚Ä¶ https://t.co/etXw9KZVw7

‚Äî LA/ENDER (@LavenderGhast) February 27, 2026

Pokemon Winds and Waves looks technically good but I still don't like them going in a realistic direction with the series

‚Äî Jade (@The_Teal_Mask) February 27, 2026

once monolith reveals their switch 2 rpg, the fucking comparisons are gonna come back üò≠ https://t.co/UjFa7ok7mV

‚Äî jin (@jingercookiee) February 27, 2026

Hey guess what, if nobody complained they wouldn't look any better. Yes they look better, so please don't stand there on your pedastal belittling the people that were pushing for this improvement in the first place.
In any case: looks p good GameFreak, not bad. https://t.co/Sy2yL1gd47

‚Äî TidyWireüçø (@TidyWire) February 27, 2026

If nothing else, as folks comb through the footage, it‚Äôs nice that loud complaints about trees or windows aren‚Äôt the primary point of discussion on day one. Pok√©mon Winds and Waves are coming to Switch 2 next year.



https://kotaku.com/pokemon-wind-waves-switch-2-graphics-comparison-images-2000674529

item.title: Today‚Äôs Wordle #1715: Hints and Answer for February 28, 2026
item.content:encoded:
Wordle challenges players to guess a fresh five-letter word each day in six tries or fewer. Whether you‚Äôre a beginner or a daily player, today‚Äôs tips and strategies can help you solve it faster and maintain your streak‚Äîif you‚Äôre open to a little extra help. So, if you‚Äôve found yourself stuck with today‚Äôs Wordle, don‚Äôt worry, below you‚Äôll find some helpful hints and even the answer for Wordle Game #1715 for February 28, 2026

To play today‚Äôs Wordle, head to the game‚Äôs website. If you want to go right to today‚Äôs answer without any tips or tricks, you can click right here.

IMPORTANT: The following information includes spoilers on today‚Äôs and yesterday‚Äôs editions of Wordle. If you don‚Äôt want the answer given to you, stop scrolling.

How To Play Wordle

Wordle is a simple but addictive word puzzle. Each day, players have to guess a five-letter word answer in no more than six attempts. After each guess:

  • Green letters are correct and in the right position.
  • Yellow letters are correct, but in the wrong position.
  • Gray letters are not in the word at all.

The goal is to guess the word in as few tries as possible. Daily puzzles keep players coming back for more, making it a fun brain exercise and a popular online trend.

Wordle can only be played on the New York Times website. There is currently no app for you to download the official game.

Wordle Hints For Today, February 28, 2026

The Wordle answer for game #1715 is another hard puzzle. According to the NY Times Wordle review, today‚Äôs answer takes an average of 5.3 out of 6 guesses. That makes it ever-so-slightly harder than the 5.2-guess average from February 27.

General Wordle Hints For February 28

Without giving today‚Äôs Wordle answer completely away, here are a few helpful hints for today to get you started:

  • Hint 1: This word refers to a specific creature, not a general category.
  • Hint 2: It‚Äôs most often encountered in mythological or symbolic contexts.
  • Hint 3: The thing it names is known more for its distinct traits than its appearance.
  • Hint 4: You‚Äôre more likely to see this word in stories or references than in everyday conversation.

Use these clues to narrow down your guesses and increase your chances of solving Wordle #1715 for February 28, 2026.

Starter Words For February 28, 2026

If you want help getting started without having today‚Äôs Wordle answer given to you, there are a few starter words worth trying that will help you figure out some included letters. A few starter words that may help are:

  • RADAR
  • DRAMA
  • HARDY
  • HYENA

Today‚Äôs Wordle Answer For Game #1715 On February 28, 2026

If you‚Äôve tried everything, including using the above hints, and are still stuck, you can find the answer to today‚Äôs Wordle below.

Answer: HYDRA

If you solved today‚Äôs Wordle without our answer, congratulations! If not, take note of the best tips above for tomorrow‚Äôs puzzle, and check back daily for more hints.

What Does Today‚Äôs Wordle Answer Mean?

HYDRA is a noun that describes, from classical mythology, ‚Äúa water or marsh serpent with nine heads, each of which, if cut off, grew back as two; Hercules killed this serpent by cauterizing the necks as he cut off the heads.‚Äù

Outside of mythology, it also means ‚Äúany freshwater polyp of the genus Hydra and related genera, having a cylindrical body with a ring of tentacles surrounding the mouth, and usually living attached to rocks, plants, etc., but also capable of detaching and floating in the water.‚Äù

Yesterday‚Äôs Wordle Answer

If you missed the previous game, here‚Äôs yesterday‚Äôs Wordle answer for Game #1714 on February 27, 2026

Answer: DIZZY

While not always the case, looking at previous words can sometimes give you insight into common patterns or letter usage in Wordle puzzles.

When Is The Next Wordle Game After #1715?

Wordle games are updated daily at 12 am or Midnight in your respective time zone. Information about the next game is often available in the hours before to give players a heads up. The game on March 1 will be Wordle Game #1716.

What Is Wordle?

Wordle is a daily word puzzle created by Josh Wardle. Initially developed as a prototype in 2013, it wasn‚Äôt fully released until 2021. The game challenges players to guess a five-letter word in six tries or fewer, using hints from each attempt to narrow down the answer. Its straightforward concept, accessibility, and the thrill of solving a new puzzle each day helped it surge in popularity by late 2021. The success of Wordle inspired numerous spin-offs and social media challenges, leading to its acquisition by The New York Times in early 2022.

For even more Insider Gaming delivered straight to your inbox, sign up for our weekly newsletter

Mike has been covering the gaming industry since 2012, and has reported on some of the largest events in the industry while also working as an investigative reporter. Outside of‚Ä¶

More from Mike Straw

item.title: This Video Of The McDonald‚Äôs CEO Struggling To Eat The New Big Arch Burger Is Cracking People Up
item.content:encoded:
McDonald‚Äôs CEO and chairman Chris Kempczinski recently had to do the one part of the job I assume he dreads the most: Eat the food produced by his popular fast food chain. And it went about as well as you‚Äôd expect.

In a video originally posted on February 3 on Instagram, Kempczinski recorded himself eating the new Big Arch Burger for lunch in his office. The video didn‚Äôt go super viral until people started sharing it on TikTok. And after watching it, I can see why so many people are fascinated by this short clip of a rich man eating a burger. But first the clip. Take it away, Chris K!

Where to start? First off, just a note from a human being who eats food, but perhaps you shouldn‚Äôt refer to your new hamburger as a ‚Äúproduct.‚Äù It feels like a lawyer told him off-camera that, legally, it can‚Äôt be called food, so he should just call it a product. Once he‚Äôs done hyping it up, content creator Chris K opens it up and exclaims, ‚ÄúHoly cow.‚Äù Then, after looking over the burger, he looks at the camera with a flash of regret and says, ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs so much going on with this.‚Äù You sound thrilled to eat it, buddy.

The CEO of McDonald‚Äôs then takes what I can only describe as the smallest bite of a burger I‚Äôve ever seen. It looks like a kid having to try some vegetable he doesn‚Äôt want to eat, but is forced by his mom to eat just a tiny bit. In the moment after eating it, you can tell he‚Äôs not happy about it, but he bravely soldiers on. He‚Äôll ask for a bigger bonus during the next round of negotiations and will point to this video as a reason why. He claims this is his lunch. Readers, I‚Äôm doubtful that the burger got finished.

And look, I love me some McDonald‚Äôs. I don‚Äôt care much for the chain‚Äôs burgers, but the rest of the menu is fine in a pinch. So don‚Äôt take this blog as me saying McDonald‚Äôs is awful. But it is funny to watch a very rich man forced to eat food that he‚Äôd never consume otherwise and then smile about it afterwards. Funny stuff. Thanks for the Friday giggles, Chris K!



https://kotaku.com/mcdonalds-ceo-big-arch-burger-instagram-2000674500
item.dc:creator: invalid@example.com (ResetEra_Newsbot

item.title: WWE 2K26 Soundtrack Revealed ‚Äî Linkin Park, Bad Omens, More Featured
item.content:encoded:
The full soundtrack for WWE 2K26 has been revealed.

Soundtracks in wrestling games can be very essential to the experience. The songs featured in any video game help set the tone for the action. In WWE games, they can sometimes be used as entrance themes or just hype players up prior to any given match. Most importantly, the songs featured in the game ultimately become tied to the memories players form.

Recent WWE video games have featured a mix of music genres spanning many decades. Iconic WWE soundtracks in the past have featured bands like Breaking Benjamin, the Dillinger Escape Plan, and the Red Hot Chili Peppers. Other acts such as Kid Rock, Kanye West, Poppy, and Bring Me the Horizon have also been featured. Now, it‚Äôs time to look at the full soundtrack for WWE 2K26.

Full WWE 2K26 Tracklist

The WWE 2K26 Soundtrack features plenty of hard rock. Powerman 5000‚Äôs ‚ÄúWhen Worlds Collide‚Äù makes its return to WWE games. It had been one of the featured songs in the original WWE SmackDown vs. Raw title back in 2004.

Andrew WK‚Äôs ‚ÄúParty Hard‚Äù also lands on the soundtrack. Bad Omens x ERRA‚Äôs ‚ÄúAnything > Human,‚Äù and Turnstile‚Äôs ‚ÄúDull‚Äù represent today‚Äôs era of Rock.

Check out the full soundtrack below:

  • ‚ÄúDull‚Äù ‚Äì Turnstile
  • ‚ÄúTwo Faced‚Äù ‚Äì Linkin Park
  • ‚ÄúReckless‚Äù (feat. Denzel Curry) ‚Äì Hanumankind
  • ‚ÄúExtral‚Äù ‚Äì Jennie
  • ‚ÄúDiamonds and Guns‚Äù ‚Äì Transplants
  • ‚ÄúWhen Worlds Collide‚Äù ‚Äì Powerman 5000
  • ‚ÄúAnything > Human‚Äù ‚Äì Bad Omens x ERRA
  • ‚ÄúCruising to Self Soothe‚Äù ‚Äì Ecca Vandal
  • ‚ÄúQu√© M√°s Quieres‚Äù ‚Äì The Warning
  • ‚ÄúParty Hard‚Äù ‚Äì Andrew W.K.
  • ‚ÄúBender‚Äù (feat. Travis Barker) ‚Äì The Paradox
  • ‚ÄúLie Between the Lines‚Äù ‚Äì Better Lovers
  • ‚ÄúThe Black Curtain‚Äù ‚Äì Gatecreeper
  • ‚ÄúMan Made of Meat‚Äù ‚Äì Viagra Boys
  • ‚ÄúUpside Down‚Äù ‚Äì Ho99o9
  • ‚ÄúHeathens‚Äù ‚Äì The Mistakes

WWE 2K26 is set to release worldwide on March 13. Premium edition purchases provide 7-Day Early Access.

Are you excited for WWE 2K26‚Äôs soundtrack? Sound off in our official Discord server. For more WWE 2K26, learn about the changes coming to DLC via the Ringside Pass. Also, don‚Äôt forget to sign up for our weekly newsletter.

item.title: Until Then coming to Xbox Series in 2026 alongside DLC ‚ÄòAfterimages‚Äô
item.content:encoded:
• PC
  • PS5
  • Switch
  • Xbox Series

New content introduces two new chapters.

Publisher Maximum Entertainment and developer Polychroma Games will release narrative adventure game Until Then for Xbox Series in 2026 alongside the downloadable content ‚ÄúAfterimages‚Äù for all platforms, the companies announced.

Until Then first launched for PlayStation 5 and PC via Steam on June 25, 2024, followed by Switch on June 26, 2025.

Here is an overview of the downloadable content, via Maximum Entertainment:

‚ÄúAfterimages‚Äù introduces two new chapters that explore grief, memory, and the quiet persistence of life in the wake of loss. Sofia returns home to confront memories she left behind. Meanwhile, Mark encounters both a new lover and an old friend. Through their separate journeys, both characters must navigate what it means to move forward while carrying the weight of absence.

Players will discover fresh gameplay moments woven into the intimate storytelling experience that defines Until Then. The downloadable content introduces new interactive activities, including tarot reading and baking minigames, alongside expanded in-game phone features such as dating apps and video platforms. Players will reconnect with beloved characters and encounter new faces across two deeply personal narrative chapters.

Watch a new trailer below. View a new set of screenshots at the gallery.

DLC ‚ÄúAfterimages‚Äù Announce Trailer

item.title: 10 Steam Next Fest Demos You Need To Try - February 2026
item.content:encoded:
It‚Äôs one of my favorite times of the year ‚Äì when game developers come out like Santa‚Äôs elves and show off what they‚Äôve been working on in their hidden little workshops. That‚Äôs right, it‚Äôs time for another Steam Next Fest, and for the February Steam Next Fest of 2026, there are over 3,500 demos for people to try.

With all those demos to try, no one can play them all. But to help you out I‚Äôve spent the last few weeks trying a bunch of them, and I‚Äôm here to point out 10 of the demos you really should check out. Some of them are popular, some of them are obscure, and I‚Äôve tried to capture a variety of genres here so that there‚Äôs something for everyone.

With all of that here are ten of the best and most interesting February 2026 Steam Next Fest Demos.

Vampire Crawlers

There were two dungeon crawlers in this Next Fest that fought for space in this top 10, and Vampire Crawlers beat out the boomer shooter inspired Dungeons of Dusk by New Blood in a messy match. Vampire Crawlers's sheer energy and style plays near perfectly mixing dungeon crawlers, roguelite deckbuilding, and the Vampire Survivors IP into a cascade of fun.

It has some distinct and unique ideas that play differently in spots like the Crawler cards, and it feels really good to play. This was a demo I lost hours in, in a way that I never really have with Vampire Survivors itself.

Voidling Bound

I originally came across Voidling Bound last year, as they released their demo originally last spring. I‚Äôm happy that I can now talk about this monster taming/collecting game in this article, because it is a lot of fun. It takes that idea of finding and collecting monsters and turns it into a third-person shooter as you take control of the little creatures, called Voidlings, and explore and battle on different missions.

The controls are snappy, the combat fluid, and the variation in creatures and abilities intriguing. Voidling Bound is at its best in its exploration levels, but there‚Äôs fun in its hoard levels as well, and the mixture makes for a compelling proposition.

Bobo Bay

Sticking with cute little creatures, if you want a less action-packed game with little dudes, Bobo Bay might be up your alley. This is a game that takes inspiration from raising sims, and the Chao Garden from Sonic Adventure and has you raising these little creatures around and putting them into competitions. 

Get them trained up, fed up, and put them into competitions that their skills are best suited to and eventually into even bigger projects. Beyond that there‚Äôs a cheerful energy that infuses the game, and it's fun to move around in a way that a lot of games just don‚Äôt have.

Battlestar Galactica: Shattered Hopes

From the persistently cheerful realm of Bobo Bay, we go to the darkness of space, and that no less of the 12 Colonies. In command of a small fleet escaping the Cylon destruction, you must guide them through tough decisions and difficult battles as you attempt to rejoin the Battlestar Galactica with your own ship and the civilians you are protecting. More than anything, Shattered Hopes captures the feel of the modern Battlestar Galactica with the grimness, the desperation, and the constant need to keep moving.

It‚Äôs not the highest production tie-in, nor are its battles incredibly complicated, but they are tense, short, and designed to press you to make decisions and accept tradeoffs before you are able to jump away.

Fading Echo

This is a fast-paced action-adventure RPG game where you find yourself in control of elements and able to reshape the world around you with it. Turn into a ball of water like Samus‚Äô morph ball and use that to put out fires or bounce around and through the water. 

Add in some cheek, and other elements to play with and Fading Echo is a lot of fun to move around, to explore, to solve puzzles, and fight in.

Celestial Return

A story-driven RPG experience, Celestial Return posits a dark, and intriguing world where you play as a burnt-out detective who decides to care one last time. Disco Elysium meets Blade Runner with an intriguing way of handling luck by treating dice as a resource used for just about everything, and they come in a variety of forms. Combine that with a unique aesthetic and this is a must-play game.

Darkhaven

Like many of my generation, I grew up with Diablo 2, and that game is still shaping things with its new expansion and everything else. Somewhere along the way though, the ARPG genre kinda decided that it had already reached peak and just began doing small tweaks on the same format. Don‚Äôt get me wrong, I love games like Torchlight too, but I also wonder if anyone was going to ever move the line.

Well, some of the Diablo and Torchlight crew are back with Darkhaven and their big idea is essentially to mix the ARPG with survival games. Take the items and quests and mix that with the building and destructible world of Minecraft, and you know what it? It works. The whole part of the world being so changeable creates significant differences in how the game plays, and new exploration options. Building here is kept simple so you aren‚Äôt tracking 30 things, and it gives the game a distinct feel.

Darkhaven‚Äôs demo here is rawer than others, as the game is also currently on Kickstarter seeking funding for another year of development. Right now what you have is a pre-alpha where you can see a lot of the seams and raw edges showing, but there‚Äôs a lot of promise here and room for something that is very different from what came before.

Titanium Court

The most surreal game I experienced throughout Next Fest, Titanium Court is out there and it is weird in many many ways. The fourth wall gets leaned on, the world in it is odd, and its got weird-as-hell characters and interface interactions at times that delight in their surreal absurdism.

While that might be enough to get interest, what you‚Äôll find underneath is a deep strategy matching game that is unique in how it plays. The closest in someways is something like Drop Dutchy, but this focuses on match-3 type mechanics, and how different types of blocks and your subjects all interact as you try to maximize returns, minimize invasions, and find your way through a bizarre and compelling narrative.

Windrose

One of the interesting things you can watch at times on Steam is the population of survival-craft players. They emerge from one and will seemingly migrate en masse to another game. Sometimes you can even predict what the next one will be ‚Äì and Windrose looks like it.

And I mean, why not? It looks good, it's a golden age of piracy themed survival game, and it plays pretty well too. It has a bit more combat depth then many of these games, but features all the same tracks you would expect while having a few different things and a focus on sailing and finding treasure that you don‚Äôt see elsewhere necessarily in the genre. Arr Matey, hoist the jolly roger and prepare to battle as we seek revenge on Blackbeard himself!

Vultures - Scavengers of Death

Have you ever wondered, what would Resident Evil be like if it was turn based? Well you don‚Äôt need to really wonder any more, as Vultures ‚Äì Scavengers of Death here presents a pitch-perfect take on the '90s horror styling turned into a tactics type experience. Seek what is causing the infected mutants (totally not zombies) to cause problems while managing your scarce resources and gathering more.

Avoid combat where you can, beat enemies where you must, and wonder ‚Äì what is that around that corner?

A longtime lover of speculative fiction, in almost all its forms, Don joined TechRaptor in 2014 on a whim sending in an application as he was looking for‚Ä¶ More about Don



https://techraptor.net/gaming/features/10-february-2026-steam-next-fest-demos-you-need-to-try
item.dc:creator: invalid@example.com (ResetEra_Newsbot

item.title: Super Pocket Rare Edition Brings 14 Titles Including Banjo-Kazooie
item.content:encoded:
Play classic Rare games, including Banjo-Kazooie, Evercade cartridges, and more on the brand new Super Pocket Rare Edition. The handheld, which is made by HyperMegaTech, is slated for release in June 2026. An exact date has not been specified.

The handheld, which is made by HyperMegaTech, is slated for release in June 2026. An exact date has not been specified.

The item will be priced at $69 in the United States of America. It will also cost ¬£49 in the United Kingdom and ‚Ç¨59 throughout other parts of Europe. Pre-orders are available now.

What Games Will Be Playable on Super Pocket Rare Edition? Built-In Titles Explained

In addition to the ability to play Evercade cartridges, the handheld will have 14 Rare-developed classic titles built in. The 14 games span a wide range of the company‚Äôs history, including their days making games for the ZX Spectrum.

Popular titles like Battletoads are also included, as is Conker‚Äôs Pocket Tails, the Game Boy Color predecessor to Conker‚Äôs Bad Fur Day on the Nintendo 64

Check out the full list of games below:

  • Atic Atac
  • Banjo-Kazooie
  • Battletoads in Battlemaniacs
  • Battletoads
  • Cobra Triangle
  • Conker‚Äôs Pocket Tails
  • Gunfright
  • Jetpac
  • Knight Lore
  • Lunar Jetman
  • R.C. Pro-Am II
  • Slalom
  • Snake Rattle‚ÄôN‚ÄôRoll
  • Solar Jetman

Are you excited for this forthcoming handle? Will you be pre-ordering? Sound off in our official Discord server. Also, don‚Äôt forget to sign up for our weekly newsletter.

item.title: Nintendo Announces $70 Mini Game Boy That's Designed to Be a Jukebox, With Dozens of Cartridges That Play Pok√©mon Music From 30 Years Ago
item.content:encoded:
Buried between fresh footage of Pok√©mon Pokopia and today's truly momentous Gen 10 announcement for Pok√©mon Winds and Waves, Nintendo announced a miniature version of its legendary Game Boy ‚Äî that's actually a kind of retro jukebox.

It sure looks like a Game Boy, only smaller. It also sounds like a Game Boy, and comes with classic-looking cartridges ‚Äî though these only play tunes from the original Pok√©mon games' soundtrack.

In a neat touch, the cartridges include images from Pok√©mon Red and Pok√©mon Blue that reflect the music on that particular cart. So, pop in a cartridge with the games' title screen on it, and it's the title screen music that you'll hear. Pop in a cartridge with Cycling Road on it and... you get the picture.

Sound on to be transported back to the 90s!

Listen to the same iconic sounds of the Game Boy system with the Game Music Collection. Embark on a nostalgic audio journey with 45 cartridges featuring music from the original Pok√©mon Red and Pok√©mon Blue video games that üé∂ pic.twitter.com/A0VXq1bSmM

‚Äî Pok√©mon (@Pokemon) February 27, 2026

45 songs are featured, stored on 45 cartridges. (Or are they all stored on the main miniature Game Boy, and these cartridges just tell it which to play? It is unclear.) Priced at $69.99, the Game Boy Jukebox is available to purchase now via Pok√©monCenter.com in celebration of the Pok√©mon franchise's 30th anniversary.

"Relive cherished memories of your Pok√©mon adventures in the Kanto region by embarking on a new journey to listen to the songs and sounds that helped bring it to life!" reads an official blurb. "In this special collection, you'll find Game Boy Jukebox, a sound toy modeled after the original Game Boy system from Nintendo, along with 45 cartridges that you can insert into the device to hear a familiar melody or sound effect from the original Pok√©mon video games."

Alas, there does not appear to be any headphone jack ‚Äî so you'll be listening to the tunes out loud.

Pok√©mon Gen 10 Reveal: Over 40 Stills From the Winds & Waves Trailer

Back to today's new creatures, there's a wave of love for fire pooch Pombon, though also calls for it remain standing on four legs after it evolves. For more of today's announcements, be sure to catch up on everything revealed in today's Pok√©mon Presents broadcast and all Pok√©mon species confirmed for Winds and Waves so far.

Tom Phillips is IGN's News Editor. You can reach Tom at tom_phillips@ign.com or find him on Bluesky @tomphillipseg.bsky.social



https://www.ign.com/articles/nintendo-announces-70-mini-game-boy-thats-designed-to-be-a-jukebox-with-dozens-of-cartridges-that-play-pokemon-music-from-30-years-ago

item.title: How strong is New York's "illegal gambling" case against Valve's loot boxes?
item.content:encoded:
Skip to content

Can‚Äôt win if you don‚Äôt play

Lawyers tell Ars the state has a tough road ahead, even as Valve is uniquely vulnerable.

Opening a vauable skin like this in a loot box is akin to winning a lottery, New York alleges in a new lawsuit. Credit: Twitter / Luksusbums

For years now, Valve fans have been making jokes about the company‚Äôs slow transition from game maker to glorified digital hat and knife paint marketplace. This week, though, a lawsuit brought by the state of New York argues that Valve‚Äôs in-game loot box sales amount to an illegal gambling outfit worth tens of billions of dollars.

Lawyers who have looked into the particulars of the case tell Ars that the state faces an uphill battle in convincing courts that this portion of Valve‚Äôs business legally constitutes gambling. That said, there are a few elements of the case that might make Valve legally vulnerable to the state‚Äôs arguments.

What is gambling, anyway?

For a game to legally be counted as ‚Äúgambling‚Äù in most jurisdictions, it has to pass a three-part test: a player has to pay money (1) for an outcome that‚Äôs materially determined by chance (2) in the hopes of receiving something of value (3). While buying a key to a loot box in a Valve game easily passes those first two tests, New York‚Äôs legal case will likely hinge on whether the random cosmetic items players get from those loot boxes constitute ‚Äúsomething of value‚Äù for statutory purposes.

Even though loot box purchasers don‚Äôt know what item they‚Äôll get, the fact that they know they‚Äôre getting something for their money could matter legally. ‚ÄúGambling traditionally means risking money and possibly getting nothing,‚Äù Foundation Law Group Counsel Jonathan Loiterman told Ars. ‚ÄúHere, buyers can‚Äôt lose their stake in the traditional gambling sense; they always receive an item. That looks more like buying a randomized product than placing a bet.‚Äù

In this way, Valve‚Äôs loot boxes are more akin to physical ‚Äúblind box‚Äù toy sales or collectible card packs than a game like blackjack or roulette. In the real world, these kinds of randomized sales ‚Äúare not considered gambling because the stated value of what you receive is unchanging,‚Äù Hoeg Law Firm attorney Richard Hoeg told Ars. ‚ÄúYou pay for a pack of cards, you get a pack of cards.‚Äù

That ‚Äústated value‚Äù logic can sometimes be even stronger in the digital realm, where the randomized items you get from a loot box are locked to your account and can‚Äôt easily be resold. ‚ÄúDigital sellers usually try to get around this by stating that everything sold has zero cash value, so you are always getting ‚Äònothing,‚Äô‚Äù as Hoeg put it.

Come to our Marketplace

Where Valve might have some unique legal exposure, lawyers tell Ars, is in its operation of the Steam Marketplace, where players can trade in-game items for Steam Wallet funds. Operating that kind of official exchange for players to extract value from items won ‚Äústarts to look a lot more like gambling,‚Äù Hoeg said.

‚ÄúThe problem here is 100% the ability to resell the items from the loot boxes,‚Äù attorney and video game law expert Mark Methenitis tells Ars. ‚ÄúA loot box/gacha mechanic is fine when you can‚Äôt turn around and resell the items because you‚Äôre not getting something of value. When Valve is also providing a marketplace for those items, they‚Äôve added the third element.‚Äù

Still, Loiterman said that the existence of the Steam Marketplace resale market ‚Äúmatters, but it‚Äôs not decisive‚Äù in this case. While taking a commission on digital item sales ‚Äústrengthens the argument that these items have economic value,‚Äù that fact alone ‚Äúdoesn‚Äôt transform a randomized purchase into gambling,‚Äù he added.

Part of the problem for New York‚Äôs argument is that the Steam Wallet funds players receive for selling their items can only be spent on the Steam platform, putting them a few steps away from cold, hard cash or even casino chips. And while New York‚Äôs lawsuit argues that players can get cash out of their Steam Wallets by buying and reselling Steam Deck hardware in the real world, that argument is not a legal slam dunk.

‚ÄúCalling it gambling because a user could, through several indirect steps, convert an item into cash risks stretching gambling law beyond its traditional limits,‚Äù Loiterman said. ‚ÄúIf New York‚Äôs theory wins, it raises uncomfortable questions about things like Pok√©mon cards or promotional games (e.g. McDonald‚Äôs Monopoly). Courts will be cautious about going that far.‚Äù

New York also argues that Valve tacitly endorses third-party services that allow players to easily ‚Äúcash out‚Äù their Steam inventories for real money. Whether Valve is culpable for the existence of those services is still an unsettled question in the law, Methenitis said, as it has been at least since he wrote about the legal implications of World of Warcraft‚Äòs third-party gold resellers nearly two decades ago.

‚ÄúI think companies have a pretty strong [legal] argument if they make some attempts to police [third-party resellers]‚Äîthey obviously can‚Äôt fully control what people do outside their platform,‚Äù Methenitis said. ‚ÄúBut if they turn a blind eye to it and allow it, I think they could be found liable.‚Äù Loiterman agreed that Valve ‚Äúproviding the tools that enable those [third-party] markets and tolerating them creates some degree of responsibility.‚Äù

‚ÄúJudges tend to be cautious‚Ä¶‚Äù

In the end, the lawyers Ars spoke to were generally skeptical that courts would determine that Valve‚Äôs loot box system constitutes illegal gambling. Cases making similar arguments about other loot box systems have failed in other jurisdictions, ‚Äúin part because gambling laws were drafted with casinos and lotteries in mind,‚Äù Loiterman said. ‚ÄúJudges tend to be cautious about breaking from an emerging consensus.‚Äù

Hoeg agreed that ‚Äúthe entire question [in this case] is novel, and‚Ä¶ the courts are (small-‚Äòc‚Äô) conservative institutions, not generally wanting to adopt novel arguments without direction from the legislative branches.‚Äù Even if Valve‚Äôs loot box system ‚Äúmay start to smell a bit like gambling,‚Äù Hoeg said he would ‚Äúhonestly be surprised if the courts went along with the characterization without a new law aimed at it.‚Äù

‚ÄúI view it as a weak case offered primarily for political grandstanding/coverage over real legal effect,‚Äù Hoeg concluded. ‚ÄúWe shall see, though.‚Äù

Kyle Orland has been the Senior Gaming Editor at Ars Technica since 2012, writing primarily about the business, tech, and culture behind video games. He has journalism and computer science degrees from University of Maryland. He once wrote a whole book about Minesweeper.

69 Comments



https://arstechnica.com/gaming/2026/02/how-strong-is-new-yorks-illegal-gambling-case-against-valves-loot-boxes/
item.dc:creator: invalid@example.com (ResetEra_Newsbot

item.title: Can Resident Evil Requiem Grapple With Nuclear Tragedy? Does It Even Want To?
item.content:encoded:
The Resident Evil series, historically, has been about a lot of things. Zombies, obviously, but also the global ravages of a feckless pharmaceutical company and, in its own often-campy way, the politics surrounding that. You might remember, for example, that time all of Raccoon City got obliterated by a nuclear bomb. Charged imagery, to be sure, but was Resident Evil 3 trying to say anything weighty or consequential with it back then? And what is Resident Evil Requiem, in returning to that setting, trying to say with it now? On the latest Aftermath Hours, we attempt to answer those questions.

This time around we‚Äôre joined by two critics who‚Äôve played through Requiem and articulated their thoughts about it: freelancer and Aftermath columnist Joshua Rivera and Polygon editor-at-large Giovanni Colantonio, whose review of Requiem ‚Äì which put the game in conversation with the atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki ‚Äì has drawn some pretty vocal criticism these past few days. We discuss whether or not the text of the game actually supports that kind of close thematic read.

We also discuss Resident Evil more broadly: where it‚Äôs coming from, where it‚Äôs going, and of course, where Requiem fits into all of that. The series has spent its past few installments promising a fresh start; does Requiem actually deliver, or is it lured astray by the siren‚Äôs call of Leon Kennedy-flavored nostalgia? And during an era that‚Äôs decidedly post-zombie, what makes this series, in particular, so enduring?

Finally, we come up with some truly diabolical remake ideas for old-school games and conclude that there‚Äôs actually no such thing as a long or short game. Who needs to stick around for 100 hours when you can make your own ending whenever you want to?

You can find this week's episode below and on Spotify, Apple, or wherever else you prefer to listen to podcasts. If you like what you hear, make sure to leave a review so that we can acquire the venerated Radical Rex license and leave it in the capable hands of Sam Eng, creator of Skate Story.

Here‚Äôs an excerpt from our conversation (edited for length and clarity):

Giovanni: It‚Äôs tough because there are specific moments ‚Äì and this is the tough thing about a pre-release write up ‚Äì I want to point to that are off limits for now, and there‚Äôs a question to be had about ‚ÄúEh, maybe that should wait [until after release] to have the full scope of the thing.‚Äù I‚Äôve always heard [Hiroshima and Nagasaki] referenced in terms of Resident Evil 3; I‚Äôve heard people talk about that. I‚Äôve never quite bought into it. I‚Äôve always thought of it like the ‚Äò90s and ‚ÄúCool guys don‚Äôt look at explosions.‚Äù Everything blows up in these games. I never paid much mind to that.

There are a couple moments in Requiem that I do think kind of, to varying degrees of explicitness, at least reference it. Not saying it specifically, but there is one case where I think it does actually point to it in a way that‚Äôs surprising. But I started thinking about it [in terms of] ‚ÄúIs this a game that is looking back at what happened in Resident Evil 3 and looking at it through the lens of a greater tragedy?‚Äù I was doing research into that, and I found an old research paper from 2019 that was focused on [original Resident Evil director] Shinji Mikami‚Äôs work. It was a piece about unpacking a lot of that post-war feeling in his work. I don‚Äôt know that I even necessarily fully agree with that research paper. There were some parts of it where I was like ‚ÄúDino Crisis fits into this? I don‚Äôt know. Seems like a stretch.‚Äù 

But I think it got the wheels turning, and with some of the symbols and lines that are in Requiem, I got to thinking about if this is a game about Leon dealing with a trauma that is referencing the trauma [of nuclear devastation]? And are we supposed to take it as he‚Äôs experiencing this long aftermath of this trauma that‚Äôs coming from a real place of anxiety?

So that‚Äôs how I got onto that train of thought, and I do think there are things you can point to that are there. I think the question that arises, though, is: Even if that stuff is there, is Resident Evil equipped to talk about that in any way? I‚Äôve been thinking about that a lot in the past couple days. This has always been a series that has political undertones in its lore. There‚Äôs an evil Big Pharma company, and it‚Äôs making bioweapons and trading those with the US government.

Nathan: Zombie president!     

Giovanni: Yeah, there‚Äôs weird threads. They‚Äôve always been kinda funny, but there‚Äôs also stuff in there that‚Äôs very strange and pointed. A distrust for authority is baked into all of Shinji Mikami‚Äôs work ‚Äì even Dino Crisis. So the question that arises for me that I haven‚Äôt fully unpacked yet is, even if that‚Äôs what the reference is ‚Äì and I think it‚Äôs fair to say ‚ÄúEh, that‚Äôs probably a stretch‚Äù ‚Äì is Resident Evil as a series, a goofy thing, equipped to deal with something like that? And is any triple-A game? 

Josh, you wrote something that I really love; you say that even if games reference something like this, what do you do in the game? What does the gameplay come down to at the end of the day? Resident Evil Requiem, at the end of the day, is a big, fun shooting action game where you‚Äôre killing zombies, and zombies are the bodies of the dead. How do we feel about that [in this context]?

Josh, is there space for Resident Evil as you‚Äôve talked about it, as a work of pure schlock, to talk about things and reference them, or should we take it as being a little too dumb to really say anything serious about this ‚Äì and interpreting it that way is kind of a fool‚Äôs errand?

Joshua: I think it‚Äôs a fool‚Äôs errand. I also think the series is capable of [aspiring to something more serious] if they wanted to. My example in support of this is actually Resident Evil 7, which opens with a very clear Texas Chainsaw Massacre homage. There‚Äôs some hicksploitation going on there. And it has a scene at the very end where you link with the mold, which is the evil presence ‚Äì it‚Äôs very silly ‚Äì that‚Äôs made these people what they are. That neglect from this pharmaceutical company poisoned these people‚Äôs land and turned them into monsters. You get to speak with the real Jack Baker, a sympathetic, tragic figure.

I think the game means that. I think the people behind the game were interested in some type of pathos because that‚Äôs part of what they wanted to do with that game: ground you not just in Ethan Winters and the first-person [perspective], but also relating to these characters as you would in the first-person. 

So I do think the games are capable of it; I don‚Äôt think this game is interested in that. I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs crazy for someone to see what you saw, Gio, and to consider it in relation to the game. But I do think there is a matter of scope and justification. That‚Äôs a big check that you write ‚Äì that anybody writes if they‚Äôre pulling from something outside of the text. The sticking point for me, then, is ‚ÄúHow do I justify referencing a real historical tragedy and also a people in connection to that tragedy?‚Äù

The first thing I would go to is just a simple question of visual language. I think about 9/11; because of the generation we‚Äôre a part of, most people in the creative workforce are about our age or older. We have a visual language for how a city falls apart. We have a very specific image culturally for what that looks like. So if we are going to show a city falling apart, that is what we‚Äôre gonna think of and that is what we‚Äôre gonna replicate. Does it mean that the work in which we do that is about that? Not necessarily. Then again, this is also a matter of interpretation and intent. They could be totally separate things. This is what [the concept of] death of the author talks about.

For example, The Avengers. That‚Äôs very much a movie about ‚ÄúWhat if we could stop 9/11?‚Äù That‚Äôs not necessarily what the people who made that movie were thinking, but that‚Äôs kind of what‚Äôs in that movie. Or the new Superman movie ‚Äì maybe less so. I think that movie has different aims. 

You put even more of a burden of proof on yourself when you also invoke a people and a place and a culture in addition to the imagery of a historical event. That‚Äôs where I‚Äôve got my guard up. I‚Äôm gonna call out something specifically, and it was not something that was in your review; this is something I saw in defense of your review from people who read it, and it really bugged me. People were like ‚ÄúIt makes sense and it‚Äôs natural to think of Hiroshima in a work made by Japanese people featuring a bombed city.‚Äù It‚Äôs one of those ‚ÄúListen to yourself‚Äù moments. Natural for you. That is your only frame of reference for this place, this people, this culture. You swap out any other atrocity with any other group of people, and fuck you, you know? ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs natural for this Latino man to be evoking colonialism and the conquest of Borinquen.‚Äù Listen to yourself. 

I think what‚Äôs interesting ‚Äì and what I struggle with a little bit in your reading, Giovanni ‚Äì is that you do evoke the Hibakusha [bombing survivors]. We know how Japanese culture evokes that imagery. They were a protected class. There is a very sober and sacred evocation of these people and what they went through. If we think this is something that is being referenced, I think we would also see that somber, careful treatment [in Requiem]. And I don‚Äôt think that‚Äôs there. So for me, that‚Äôs not where I would go.

Giovanni: Yeah, fair enough. I think that‚Äôs a really interesting way to read it, because yeah, I agree: If we are talking about survivors, this is a tough series to put that into! And again, I do think there are little references to it ‚Äì there are things to my read that that‚Äôs coming from ‚Äì but I don‚Äôt think that necessarily means that‚Äôs what the game is about.

I would actually argue, and I want to make this clear: I think the game, if we‚Äôre giving it an About, is very broadly about trauma. It‚Äôs about Grace experiencing it on this micro scale, dealing with the loss of her mother; it‚Äôs about Leon dealing with it on a larger scale of ‚ÄúAll these people in this city that I was sworn to protect are gone.‚Äù It‚Äôs having two characters face that in very different ways ‚Äì almost a fight or flight response between them. That‚Äôs what I would say the game is actually about, and that‚Äôs the wider point that I would point to if we were getting into that. 

But yeah, I agree: If the intent is to invoke this [real-world tragedy], it‚Äôs certainly not terribly respectful. And I think that‚Äôs a good point, to be like ‚ÄúWell, you would think that they would be more respectful if that was the case.‚Äù I think that‚Äôs legitimate.

Recommended



https://aftermath.site/podcasts/aftermath-hours-podcast-resident-evil-requiem/
item.dc:creator: invalid@example.com (ResetEra_Newsbot

item.title: Pokemon FireRed & LeafGreen Aurora Ticket and Mystic Ticket Confirmed in Switch Ports
item.content:encoded:
It's apparently been confirmed that Pokemon FireRed and LeafGreen on Switch have a quality-of-life feature that will make catching certain legendary Pokemon much, much easier.

As spotted by Professor Rex on X (and isn't that pleasing to say?), a Japanese speedrunner has uncovered a neat change in the Switch versions of the GBA classics, and it pertains to the Aurora Ticket and Mystic Ticket items.

In the original Game Boy Advance games, obtaining these tickets was only possible through Mystery Gift events, so if you wanted to catch the legendary Pokemon Deoxys, Ho-Oh, and Lugia, you'd need to have been around during those events. Now, that's no longer the case.

In the Switch version, however, both of those tickets are simply automatically handed to you upon beating the Elite Four, at least according to the aforementioned Japanese speedrunner's playthrough of the game.

This means that you'll have the chance to confront Deoxys, Ho-Oh, and Lugia over the course of a normal playthrough rather than needing to be in the right place at the right time, which is great news for those of us who chronically miss these kinds of events.

Just in case you missed the news, Pokemon FireRed and LeafGreen were re-released on Switch today as part of the franchise's 30th anniversary. Nintendo has also promised that the games will feature Pokemon Home compatibility at some point in the future.

These anniversary celebrations also saw the long-awaited announcement of Pokemon's tenth generation earlier today, with Pokemon Winds and Waves due to launch exclusively on Switch 2 sometime next year.

You can check out Pokemon FireRed and LeafGreen right now on Switch 2 and Switch via the eShop (there's no physical release available for them, unfortunately). Stay tuned for more news on all things Pokemon.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He‚Äôs originally an‚Ä¶ More about Joseph



https://techraptor.net/gaming/news/pokemon-firered-leafgreen-aurora-ticket-mystic-ticket-switch-ports
item.dc:creator: invalid@example.com (ResetEra_Newsbot

item.title: This Tiny Game Boy Is Actually A $70 MP3 Player That Only Plays Pok√©mon Red And Blue Music
item.content:encoded:
The Game Boy is back but it only plays music from the Kanto region. Nintendo is spending nearly $2 billion on stock buybacks from Japanese banks. And the cool-looking He-Man brawler finally has a release date. It‚Äôs the latest edition of Morning Checkpoint, Kotaku‚Äòs daily roundup of gaming news, rumors, and culture.

I was up until 3:00 a.m. playing Marathon last night and I‚Äôm currently paying for it. There have been lots of complaints about everything from the UI to the ammo economy, but I think a lot of the complaints so far are kneejerk reactions to a rough onboarding process. The real problem is that nobody‚Äôs on proximity chat. It‚Äôs ruthless out there. Tau Ceti IV is no post-apocalyptic Calabrada.

The Game Boy Jukebox is pricey but adorable

It was revealed during today‚Äôs Pok√©mon 30th Anniversary Presents and it might be the oddest little lo-fi gadget of 2026. The Game Boy Jukebox plays music instead of games, and only from the original Red and Blue Pok√©mon games, and only if you insert one of 45 small cartridges corresponding to the track you want. It‚Äôs absurd, but I respect it.

Also, it‚Äôs $70. Which is less respectful and even more absurd. I won‚Äôt buy one, but I definitely want one. Maybe DIY chiptune artists can do some really cool homebrew hacks with it. If nothing else, it will look perfect on a shelf since we‚Äôre probably not getting an actual Game Boy classic device from Nintendo anytime soon. The Jukebox goes on sale later today.

Disgaea gets a surprise action-RPG spin-off

It‚Äôs called Disgaea Mayhem and it turns the long-running tactical JRPG series into a real-time brawl-fest. You play as a candy-loving mercenary who can wield all the weapons you‚Äôd find in your standard Disgaea entry. I‚Äôm not gonna lie, the action looks floaty and stiff in the trailer, but there are lots of big numbers, and I‚Äôm sure endless dungeons to grind. It hits Switch, PS5, and PC this summer.

It‚Äôs raining XP in Fallout 76 after the game‚Äôs 66th update

As PC Gamer reports, all the in-game events have been buffed. The XP they award now scales with your level; some of them are shorter, so they feel less tedious and unrewarding, and revised icons make it easier to tell which event is which on the map. It might be time to go back to Appalachia for a bit.

Nintendo is doing a massive $1.9 billion stock buyback

That‚Äôs a lot of cash to burn making anxious investors happy. Reuters reports that it‚Äôs mostly big institutional banks like MUFG Bank and the Bank of Kyoto selling shares back to Nintendo following political pressure to have companies insulate one another less from outside shareholders.

The new retro He-Man beat-em-up finally has a release date

A new trailer confirms the Saturday-special-looking He-Man and the Masters of the Universe: Dragon Pearl of Destruction will be out April 28 across console and PC. It looks cool as heck and very old-school, though hopefully it plays better than some of the other licensed retro brawlers in recent years. It‚Äôll be out just a month and change shy of the new movie‚Äôs arrival in theaters.

A former Xbox executive gives the new one some advice

‚ÄúI wish her all the best,‚Äù Xbox‚Äôs old E3 tattoo artist Peter Moore told GamesBeat about new Microsoft Gaming CEO Asha Sharma. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs in a position right now where‚Äìkeep your head down. Fly low. Avoid the radar. Learn, listen. Spend a lot of time internally. Travel the world. Meet with the studio heads. Do the classic listening tour, which a lot of executives do. I think she‚Äôll be fine. She‚Äôs gotta explain AI and her background. That‚Äôs a minefield. I would, for me, avoid talking about that if you possibly can. But I wish her all the best.‚Äù

ICYMI:

  • Gamers are picking sides in the unexpected gambling lawsuit against Valve
  • Demon Tides has the wonderfully breezy spirit of a classic PlayStation platformer
  • The makers of Project Windless didn‚Äôt expect its swole chicken to steal the show at this month‚Äôs State of Play

Watch this:

Legend of @BalatroGame DrSpectred aka Balatro University hits the naneinf with No Jokers Equipped and a 755 card deck pic.twitter.com/oaadtzqGPe

‚Äî Yung Skrrt‚Ñ¢ (@yungskrrt) February 22, 2026



https://kotaku.com/game-boy-pokemon-music-preorder-sale-buy-2000674485
item.dc:creator: invalid@example.com (ResetEra_Newsbot

item.title: Battlefield 6 1.2.1.5 Update Improves Stability and Gameplay
item.content:encoded:
Updates have been announced for Battlefield 6 in version 1.2.1.5

The Battlefield Communications team announced the next update to the game. This next update focuses on quality-of-life improvements, stability fixes, and the resolution of issues across a wide variety of game modes and overall gameplay.

Touted Quality-of-Life Updates Coming to Battlefield 6

The new update is scheduled to go live on March 3. Among the major updates are additional stability improvements to prevent crashes. Also, the team says they have improved the front-end for a smoother experience.

Plus, they say they‚Äôve restored missing Store items to player inventory. These items are from the Bountiful Harvest, Pax Vanguard, and Devil Dogs bundles.

Additional Improvements Coming in New Update

Other updates to Battlefield 6 that players may be interested in include updated spawn logic with an additional out-of-combat area check to prevent unintended spawn locations. Also, they have addressed the issue that saw Battle Pass rewards on the active path could display placeholder text or missing icons.

On the REDSEC front, they‚Äôve tackled the issue in Battle Royale Duos where pings weren‚Äôt displayed in the elimination feed. Also, they fixed the issue where the Tracking Pulse Recon trait could activate when destroying any deployable gadget.

Other issues related to Portal stability, audio, and more were addressed. Players can check out the full statement here.

Do these improvements make you want to play more Battlefield 6? Sound off in our official Discord server. Also, don‚Äôt forget to sign up for our weekly newsletter. 

MOBILE APP

Level Up Your Gaming News

Real-time news, exclusive podcasts, push alerts, and a better reading experience.

Available on iOS & Android



https://insider-gaming.com/battlefield-6-1-2-1-5-update-improves-stability-and-gameplay/

item.title: PEPPERED: An Existential Platformer coming to PS5, Xbox Series, PS4, Xbox One, and Switch on April 7
item.content:encoded:
• PS4
  • PS5
  • Switch
  • Xbox One
  • Xbox Series

Narrative-driven 2D platforming game set for consoles.

Publisher Lynxbyte Games and developer Mostly Games will release narrative-driven 2D platforming game PEPPERED: An Existential Platformer for PlayStation 5, Xbox Series, PlayStation 4, Xbox One, and Switch on April 7, the companies announced.

PEPPERED: An Existential Platformer first launched for PC via Steam on April 7, 2025.

Here is an overview of the game, via Lynxbyte Games:

About

PEPPERED: An Existential Platformer is an existential platformer where you have ONE SHOT at everything.

Every choice, every boss battle, and every failure impact the branching plotline and determine how the story will go and how it will end. Will you save the world‚Äîor fail miserably?

Synopsis

Seeing apathy in the face of doomsday, an office intern decides to save the world by themselves. But the world responds by summoning the police, angry mobs, and the media, branding them as a terrorist.

Key Features

  • Branching Narrative ‚Äì Multiple endings. Multiple story routes. Your failures and choices affect the story, which branches out heavily‚Äîsometimes taking you to completely unique locations with unique scenes, characters, or gameplay mechanics.
  • Platforming Action ‚Äì Run. Jump. Die. Scream at the screen.
  • One-Shot Boss Fights ‚Äì Challenging boss fights! If you lose, the game will not reset or give you a second chance‚Äîit will go on, incorporating your loss and changing the story accordingly.
  • Choices ‚Äì Make story choices, ranging from dialogue responses to actions. These will either affect the characters, the scene‚Äôs outcome, or the ending you get.
  • Stealth Sections ‚Äì Get caught, sneak past, or find a secret solution. Every section features a unique character, permanent outcomes, and dumb gags.
  • Exploration ‚Äì Immerse yourself in a bizarre world full of weirdos and sad people! Talk with colorful NPCs, poke around the environment, or ignore it all.
  • Completely Random Crap ‚Äì Maybe you‚Äôll have to use a shopping cart to run away from thugs? Perhaps you‚Äôll have to write a presentation or gamble with a street corner lunatic? Who knows? (I do.)
  • An Office Chair ‚Äì You can spin in it.
